awd_titl_txt: IDBR: TYPE A; Optical Microresonators as Platforms for Probing Single Metalloproteins in Action
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to the University of Wisconsin Madison to enable measurements on individual metal-containing enzymes. The remarkable catalytic activities of enzymes frequently derive from the properties of a metal atom within the enzyme. Typically, studies of how these metalloenzymes function rely on trapping the enzyme in different intermediate states, a process that cannot always reveal the entire enzyme mechanism.  Single-molecule measurements, i.e. studies performed on one molecule at a time, are powerful tools for understanding function because they allow one to acquire "molecular movies" of chemical behavior. However, metalloenzymes cannot be examined by state-of-the-art single-molecule techniques, necessitating the development of a new instrument. The use of optical microresonators, devices that confine light to a small microvolume, will enable the measurement of time-resolved behavior and deduce the mechanism of an individual working metalloenzyme. The results of this work will be a new tool capable of providing unique information on a broad range of enzymes critical for biological and industrially relevant chemical transformations. Simultaneously, the educational experience for participating students will be highly multidisciplinary, incorporating elements of photonics, instrumentation, nanofabrication, and bioinorganic chemistry. This project will also include the development of biophotonics teaching modules, participation of undergraduate students under-represented in STEM fields, and undergraduate students at a PUI.         

This purpose of this project is to develop a spectrometer capable of measuring time-resolved electronic absorption spectra of individual biomolecules. The proposed research will benefit the large scientific community studying metalloenzymes.  Enzymes are the biological machines that support nearly all metabolic activity in biological organisms. At the heart of nearly half of these machines is a metal ion that facilitates protein function. These metalloenzymes go through multiple individual kinetic steps in order to carry out their function, including electron transfer events and ligand binding and dissociation. It is of immense mechanistic interest to establish the nature and timescale of these individual events in the enzyme's catalytic cycle. Single-molecule measurements offer the unique ability to construct 'molecular movies' of enzymes performing their natural functions. These measurements are extremely powerful for enabling a greater understanding of how enzymes function since each step can potentially be observed. However, even as modern single-molecule techniques have enabled critical details of many enzymes to be unraveled, current methods for performing measurements on individual molecules fail to provide useful information about the metal site in metalloenzymes, essentially remaining blind to the most important mechanistic details of metalloenzyme mode of operation. This proposal concerns the development of a new technique to allow single-molecule investigation of the active sites of metalloenzymes. Specifically, we will develop optical microresonators as highly sensitive thermometers capable of measuring the heat released from a single photoexcited biomolecule. Once this heat is quantified, one can infer how much light was absorbed, allowing the construction of the electronic absorption spectrum of the active site. This spectrum, which varies as a function of time as the metalloenzyme carries out its function, contains a tremendous amount of information about the changing nature of the metal site, including its redox state and coordination environment. This new technique will open up a substantial fraction of a critical biomolecule class to be probed at the single molecule level, enabling new opportunities for a large community of researchers.

por.por_cntn:
Professor Randall Goldsmith and Thomas Brunold of the University of Wisconsin Madison have successfully completed their goal of developing a new photonic technology to investigate the chemical dynamics of individual molecules.  Single-molecule measurements are a critical technology for understanding the mechanism of biological molecules because they allow unsynchronized chemical dynamics to be directly observed.  However, only molecules that emit light, fluorescent molecules, can be studied at the single-molecule level.  This project employed devices called optical microresonators, structures that can confine light to a very small volume for a relatively long amount of time, to enable spectroscopy on single particles that are NOT fluorescent.  The microresonators are capable of sensing the heat dissipated by the target molecules and particles. 

Our team first showed that optical microresonators could be used as spectrometers for single non-emissive particles.  In the process, we developed a sophisticated double modulation technique that allowed us to resolve resonance shifts down to under 1 attometer, a record in microresonator sensing. We tested the spectrometer on gold nanoparticles, and in the process, revealed an unexpected interaction between the plasmonic resonances of the gold and the photonic modes of the resonator. 

We next made advances in the materials that are used construct the microresonators, allowing more flexible fabrication and better integration with microscopes. Use of silicon oxide derived from chemically deposited silicon as opposed to crystalline silicon will allow easier incorporation of transparent substrates, a critical need for use of spectrometers.  We further showed that these transparent substrates could be thinned to readily interface with existing microscope infrastructure, enabling easier adoption of our technique.   

Finally, we showed that our single-particle spectroscopy platform could be deployed in a water environment. In particular, we showed how we could monitor the etching of individual gold nanorods in a microbubble resonator.  We were even able to show how nanorods rotated during the etching process.  We also detailed the new design considerations for operation in an aqueous environment.

 Taken together, we have found solutions to the project’s major technical challenges, and these solutions will allow an individual biological molecule, such as a metalloprotein, to be studied at the single-molecule level.  We have also synthesized and characterized a variety of target bioinorganic compounds to be used to continue the system’s development. 

This project has helped to support 4 PhD students.  These students received a highly interdisciplinary training experience that included elements of photonics, optics, nanofabrication, spectroscopy, microfluidics, and biophysics.  Students also participated in international collaboration, and visited laboratories in Germany and Japan. 

Students and PIs were also involved in a variety of activities to broaden participation in STEM.  One family of activities included hosting rural high school students in our lab to see the dynamics from individual moleucles.  Another family of activites included participation in the PEOPLE (Pre-college Enrichment Opportunity Program for Learning Excellence) program where they taught, co-taught, or helped with preparation of science lessons for low-income or STEM under-represented highschool students. Specifically, students participated in a module designed to teach photolithography, a critical tool for photonics and electronics.  One student was the teaching assistant for Chem 350: Communicating Science to the Public Via Demonstrations, where he organized staffing and attended events such as Farmers' Markets, and the Wisconsin Science Festival. At these events, science demonstrations were performed within the programmatic infrastructure of Science is Fun, WISL program.  The PIs participated in the Chemistry Opportunities Program (CHOPS) to encourage STEM-minority, low-income, and first-generation college students to pursue graduate education in chemistry.
